author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: People of color https://t.co/uLQjdziNPf

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I don’t know where to begin but right where we are: to begin to admit, and walk ourselves back step by step. To reground our desires in the present. To see our addictions and where they’ve augmented attention in some spaces and eroded attention in others is crucial right now.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: Social media now enables instantaneous and endless aspirational gazing. We’ll have to regain control over our attention, and to that end we might look towards legislation and community support to begin to end the addiction to social media, if not media and celebrity at large.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: A $35k ticket is worth less than what we have paid. We have paid too much attention. Are we using the glamour or is it using us? How have we become too distracted from our sentience, our ability to choose, to apply attention to our most intimate existential queries?

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: This timing, this seemingly socio symbolic moment, makes plain: we have taken our eyes off of the ball. We have settled for entertainment. I know what we deserve but I also feel that I know what we have not earned.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: Or is there any juxtaposition at all? (FYI, the Costume Institute is a classic wealth washing entity, initially created to allow the New York socialites of yesteryear to donate their expensive garments for a tax deduction, not to mention the tax burden of philanthropy at large.)

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: We attend to this Gala with devotion we do not show human rights or legal studies. We focus instead on a somewhat opposite show of values: a show of what the most privileged bodies may perform. What “can” be “achieved juxtaposed so (in)elegantly with what “MUST” be controlled…

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: The night the decision is leaked, many of us are commenting on such trivialities as whether the celebrity class make good historians, and… OBVIOUSLY the lion share do not.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: [I am reminded of Shadrack from Sula, who can’t bear to look at his own hands… they have, under imperialism, ceased to act on his own interests, he questions self at large]

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: Tertiary considerations for me are political and theoretical if/how/should/ who regulates this? Who gets to answer these existential questions for us?

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: Secondary considerations for me include contextual ones… into what world are we birthing? Is it realistic to apply abortion bans without compromising life?

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: It brings up questions of how we came to be in this world, our earliest relations to those before us, the first moment we were desired… the consideration of when we were desire itself…if desire itself makes a life or is desire just an invitation towards livelihood…

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: Considerations of our bodies: our locus of control, autonomy, DNA and it’s propriety, how genes can and/or do design life, when life begins? What LIFE means and what it is worth… is it DNA, heartbeat, sentience? Capacity for learning, connection, pleasure?

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: Of course the abortion debate, euphemistically referred to as the “right to choose,” calls up the most existential considerations at many levels.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I’m still reeling as I process the grief at having lost Roe…to have been born in to a post Roe world, have come of sexual age, of corporeal and cognitive control, in this world, to see this protection slip away, NOT before our eyes, but somewhat quietly and out of view feels…

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I am a Virgo moon, cancer rising … https://t.co/r5OZSfWEZp

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I love making my own energy. I’m thankful to God. My body is a miracle.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I love how each part of my body responds to the others. They’re a fucking team, and I’ve learned so much from my individual ecology.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I love how my body has attempted to balance itself, although it has made for a life of injuries.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I love how my digestive system has caused me to consider acidity and balance and timing. I love how much I have learned about biology and the uniqueness of my biome.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I love how I have learned about bloating so intimately.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I love how my body is so quick to vomit. I love how reactive my sense of disgust is.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I love how my body sheds, scars, holds and refuses.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I love how my body forces rest.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I love it how the body knows when NOT to heal a wound… like baby, we gonna need to be raw for a little bit longer to work this out.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: IDK I DO think @XtineQuinn jokes are hilarious… she’s not a saint, but she keeps it real and she says the shit plainly. I see how that is not a LA copacetic vibe… I want her around but it’s a clear cultural misalignment… also Is she a Gemini? #sellingsunsets5

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I always wonder what this heightened sense does for my psychology… I do think heightened likelihood for disgust makes me less willing to put up with situations that ‘smell like shit.’

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: I can smell when people have an infection or when they’re extra stressed. I can smell when they have internal bleeding or gum disease. I can smell peoples digestive systems sometimes…

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: Look I’m not always the freshest flower, but I literally have to avoid people I love because of a mineral in their sweat or other personal odors. It is overwhelming for me.

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: Not to be all woe is me about having a literal super sense, but being a super smeller is mostly just really inconvenient…

author: Mandy Harris Williams
text: One of my most consistent dream genres is my plants having grown some unreasonable amount overnight 🙇🏾‍♀️
